title: Practice Challenge
description: Apply what you've learned in this interactive coding challenge.
instructions:
Create unit tests for a StringHelper class!

1. Create a StringHelper class with methods:
   - Reverse(string s) - Reverses a string
   - IsPalindrome(string s) - True if string reads same forwards/backwards
   - CountWords(string s) - Counts words separated by spaces

2. Write tests for each method:
   - Test Reverse with normal string
   - Test IsPalindrome with 'racecar' (true) and 'hello' (false)
   - Test CountWords with 'hello world' (2 words)
   - Test edge case: empty string

Use [Fact] for single tests, [Theory] for multiple inputs!

hints.text: AAA Pattern: Arrange (setup), Act (call method), Assert (verify). Every test follows this structure!
[Fact] for single test cases. [Theory] with [InlineData] for multiple inputs testing same logic.
Assert.Equal(expected, actual): EXPECTED FIRST! Common mistake is reversing the order.
Edge cases matter! Test empty strings, nulls, single characters. These often reveal bugs.

commonMistakes.consequence: Assert.Equal(actual, expected) produces confusing failure messages! 'Expected: [your result], Actual: [what you expected]'. Always put expected FIRST.
commonMistakes.correction: Use Assert.Equal(expected, actual). Think: 'I expect THIS, and the actual result is THAT'.

commonMistakes.consequence: Code works for 'hello' but crashes on empty string or null! Real apps receive unexpected inputs. Edge cases reveal bugs.
commonMistakes.correction: Always test: empty string, null, single element, very large inputs, negative numbers, boundary values.

commonMistakes.consequence: Tests break when you refactor! If you test 'list has 3 items after calling private method X', refactoring X breaks tests. Test PUBLIC behavior.
commonMistakes.correction: Test WHAT code does, not HOW it does it. Test inputs and outputs, not internal implementation details.

commonMistakes.mistake: Multiple asserts per test (without good reason)
commonMistakes.consequence: First failure stops the test! Other assertions never run. Hard to know full scope of failure.
commonMistakes.correction: Prefer one logical assertion per test. Multiple asserts OK if testing one cohesive thing (like all properties of returned object).
